title: How to Get Rid of Your Accumulated Junk

steps.headline: Start small- just a few minutes each day will make a big difference.
Put down the credit card.
steps.description: All this stuff came from somewhere. Try to enact some measures to stem the flow. A very good method of preventing impulse buys is to use cash and only bring enough for your planned purchases. Not only will you buy less junk - you will save your money!

steps.headline: Make good use of Ebay, Amazon, and Craigslist.
steps.description: What is junk to you may be valuable to someone else.

steps.headline: Consignment stores, antique dealers, thrift stores, and pawn shops all want your junk.
Join Kashless, and also see if your area has a Freecycle group.
steps.description: These are locale-based free exchange groups where people post items that they no longer need, but that might still have use or value for someone. No cash/barter allowed.

steps.headline: Donate what you can't or don't want to sell.
steps.description: It can be tricky, but if you take the time to find a charity that you really support, you will always know where to send your stuff.

steps.headline: Check with Earth 911 to determine how to throw away the rest.
steps.description: Earth 911 can search for nearby places to take all your donations, recyclables, and hazardous waste. If Earth 911 doesn't have anything to say, you can take it to the dump with a totally clean conscience.

steps.headline: Be decisive.
steps.description: If you haven't used something in several years, get rid of it!

steps.headline: Keep up the progress- every day throw away a bit more junk.
Organize the items you decided to keep.

text: Start small- just a few minutes each day will make a big difference.  Put down the credit card. All this stuff came from somewhere. Try to enact some measures to stem the flow. A very good method of preventing impulse buys is to use cash and only bring enough for your planned purchases. Not only will you buy less junk - you will save your money! Make good use of Ebay, Amazon, and Craigslist. What is junk to you may be valuable to someone else. Consignment stores, antique dealers, thrift stores, and pawn shops all want your junk.  Join Kashless, and also see if your area has a Freecycle group. These are locale-based free exchange groups where people post items that they no longer need, but that might still have use or value for someone. No cash/barter allowed. Donate what you can't or don't want to sell. It can be tricky, but if you take the time to find a charity that you really support, you will always know where to send your stuff. Check with Earth 911 to determine how to throw away the rest. Earth 911 can search for nearby places to take all your donations, recyclables, and hazardous waste. If Earth 911 doesn't have anything to say, you can take it to the dump with a totally clean conscience. Be decisive. If you haven't used something in several years, get rid of it! Keep up the progress- every day throw away a bit more junk.  Organize the items you decided to keep.
